Public/private partnerships crucial to meet demand for affordable housing
MELBOURNE: Public/private partnerships are crucial to be able to meet demand for affordable housing says a researcher.

Growth in Melbourne’s urban fringe offers the opportunity of adding affordable housing stock but we might repeat past mistakes. Population growth mustn’t outpace infrastructure growth. Systemic issues are holding the city back! Follow me on TikTok:
RT @SaulEslake: I spoke with Melbourne radio 3AW's @TomElliott3AW yesterday afternoon about why the housing policies of successive governme…

Melb faces a rental housing crisis as many rental properties are in short supply now. Melb vacancy rate peaked at 5.3% during pandemic and has now dropped to 1.8%. There are many rental properties for lease that are now seeing multiple tenants apply

@HankMeyerNAPP They’ll probably build a monstrosity commission housing tower on it. They did the same thing next door to me in melbourne. The rezoned their own blocks to allow them to build up to four storeys. I sold my house before it was finished.

@HulbertOld @taipan168 @VicIndyMovement Right. So you understand that $580k per bed is about 4x the cost of what building normal social housing is in inner Melbourne. They could have built two towers to house 2,000+ persons in total with this money and all the services with it. Instead we have an empty facility
